div.l: Lo hiere oure siluer redy for to spende
The Miller to the toun his douȝter sende
For Ale and bred and rosted hem a goos
And bond here hors it shuld nomore go loos
And in his chambre he made a bedde
With shetes and chalons faire I spred
Nouȝt from his ougne bed x foot or xij
His douȝter had a bed al be hirselue
Riȝt in the same chambre by and by
It miȝt be no bet and cause why
Ther was no romer herbergh in the place
They suppen̄ and speken hem to solas
And drinken euer strong Ale ate beste
Aboute midniȝt went they to reste
Wel hath this Mellere vernisshed his hed
Full pale he was ⁊and dronken ⁊and nouȝt red
He yoxeth and he spekith throuȝ the nose
As he were on the quakke or on the pose
To bedde he goth ⁊and with him goth his wif
As any Iay he liȝt was and iolif
So was her iolif whistell wel wette
The cradell at his beddes feet is set
To rokke and to yiue the childe souke
And whan that dronken was al in the crouke
To bedde went the douȝter riȝt anon̄
To bedde goth Aleyn and also Iohn
Ther is nomore him nedeth no dwale
This Miller hath so bibbed Ale
That as an hors he snoreth in his slepe
Ne of his taill behinde he took no kepe
His wif bar him a burdon̄ a full stronge
Men miȝt hiere ther routing a furlong
The wenche routyeth eke par companie
And the clerk that herd this melodie It appears that a correction was added above and between the "i" and "e" of "melodie" and then blotted.
He rokked Iohn and seide slepest thou
Herdest thou euer swilk a song or now
Lo swilk a coupling is atwix hem alle
A wilde fire on her bodyes mot falle
Who herkened euer swilk a ferly thing
They shall haue the flour of euill ending
This lange niȝt ther tides me na reste
But yit na force al shal be for the beste
For Iohn seid he as euer mot I thriue
Yef that I may yon wenche woll I swyue
Som esement hath lawe shapen vs
For Iohn there is a lawe that seith thus
That if a man̄ in oo point be agreued
That in anothir he shal be releued
Oure corn is stole sothly this is no nay
And we han had an euill fitt to day
And sith I shal haue non amendement
Agein my losse I wil haue esement
Be goddes saule it shal non othir be
This Iohn ansuerd Aleyn avise the
The Millere is a perlous man he seide
And if he be out of his slepe absreideasreideabreide
He miȝt don vs bothe a vilanie
And ansuerd I counte nat worth a flye
And vp he rist and by the wenche he crepte
This wenche lay vpriȝt and fast slepte
Til he so ny was or she miȝt spye
That it had be to late for to crye
And shortly to sein they weren aton̄
Now pley Aleyn̄ for I will speke of Iohn
This Iohn lith stille a furlong weye or tuo
And to him self he makith routhe ⁊and woo
Allas quod he this is a wickid iape
Now may I sey that I is but an ape
Yit hath my felawe somwhat for his harme
He hath the Millers douȝter in his arme
He aventred him and hath his nedes sped
And I lye lik a draf sak in my bed
And whan this Iape is told an othir day
I shal be holde a daffe a Cokenay
I woll arise and auntre it be my feith
Vnhardi is vnsely thus men seith
And vp he rose and softely he wente
Vnto the cradell ⁊and in his hand it hente
And bar it softe vnto his beddes feet
Sone after the wif her routyng leet
And gan awake and went hir out to pisse
And come agein and gan her cradell misse
And groped hiere ⁊and there and she fond non
Allas quod she I had almost misgon
I had almost gon to the clerkes bedde
Ey benedicite than̄ had I foule sped
And forth she goth till she the cradell fonde
She gropeth alwey forther with her hande
